prompt_templates.title: Generate Agent Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create an agent configuration based on this request: "[YOUR DESCRIPTION]"

Return ONLY the JSON object with identifier, whenToUse (including examples), and systemPrompt fields.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you want Claude to generate a complete agent configuration from a description

prompt_templates.title: Create Code Review Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: I need an agent that reviews code changes for [SPECIFIC CONCERNS: e.g., type safety, performance, security]. It should be triggered [WHEN: e.g., proactively after code is written, only on explicit request].
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a specialized code review agent for your project

prompt_templates.title: Validate Agent File
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the validation script on my agent file: bash scripts/validate-agent.sh agents/my-agent.md
prompt_templates.scenario: Checking if your agent file has correct structure and required fields

output_examples.input: User asks: 'How do I create an agent that generates tests?'
output_examples.output: The skill provides: (1) Complete agent file template with frontmatter, (2) System prompt pattern for test generation agents, (3) Example blocks showing when the agent should trigger, (4) Validation guidance, (5) Reference to complete-agent-examples.md for a working test-generator example

output_examples.input: User asks: 'What should go in the description field?'
output_examples.output: The skill explains: (1) Must start with 'Use this agent when...', (2) Include 2-4 <example> blocks with context, user message, assistant response, and <commentary>, (3) Show both proactive and reactive triggering, (4) Be specific about triggering conditions, (5) 200-1,000 characters recommended with concrete scenarios

best_practices: Include 2-4 concrete triggering examples in the description field with varied phrasings
Write system prompts in second person (You are..., You will...) addressing the agent directly
Use 'inherit' for model field unless the agent needs specific model capabilities
Restrict tools to minimum needed following principle of least privilege
Structure system prompts with: role description, core responsibilities, step-by-step process, quality standards, output format, and edge cases
Keep system prompts under 10,000 characters, ideally 500-3,000 characters
Choose descriptive agent identifiers (3-50 chars, lowercase-with-hyphens) that avoid generic terms
Use consistent colors across similar agent types for visual organization
Test agent triggering with scenarios similar to your examples before deployment
Validate agent files with the provided validation script before using them
anti_patterns: Using generic agent names like 'helper' or 'assistant' instead of descriptive identifiers
Writing vague descriptions without concrete triggering examples
Omitting <example> blocks or <commentary> explanations in the description
Writing system prompts in first person (I am...) or third person (The agent...)
Creating system prompts without clear process steps or output format
Granting all tools access when agent only needs read operations
Using the same color for all agents in a plugin
Skipping validation and testing before deployment
Creating descriptions under 10 characters or system prompts under 20 characters
Forgetting to define quality standards or edge case handling in system prompts

faq.question: What's the difference between an agent and a command in Claude Code?
faq.answer: Agents are autonomous subprocesses that handle complex, multi-step tasks independently. Commands are user-initiated actions. Use agents for work that requires multiple steps and decision-making, use commands for single actions triggered explicitly by users.

faq.question: How many triggering examples should I include in the description?
faq.answer: Include 2-4 concrete examples. Cover at least one explicit request and one proactive/implicit trigger. More than 6 examples makes the description too long.

faq.question: When should I restrict tools instead of giving full access?
faq.answer: Always restrict tools to the minimum needed (principle of least privilege). For read-only analysis agents use ['Read', 'Grep', 'Glob'], for code generators use ['Read', 'Write', 'Grep'], for testing use ['Read', 'Bash', 'Grep']. Only grant full access if truly necessary.

faq.question: Should I use AI-assisted generation or write agents manually?
faq.answer: Start with AI-assisted generation using the provided system prompt for comprehensive, consistent results. Then refine manually for project-specific patterns, custom tool combinations, or precise triggering conditions. This combines speed with customization.

faq.question: What model should I specify in the frontmatter?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' in most cases so the agent uses the same model as the parent. Only specify sonnet/opus/haiku if the agent has specific capability or cost requirements.

faq.question: How long should my system prompt be?
faq.answer: Aim for 500-3,000 characters (standard agent). Minimum viable is ~500 words with role, 3 responsibilities, 5-step process, and output format. Maximum is 10,000 characters before diminishing returns. Quality and specificity matter more than length.

faq.question: What goes in the <commentary> blocks in examples?
faq.answer: Explain WHY the agent should trigger in this scenario. Include decision logic like 'Code was just written, proactively review for quality' or 'Explicit security analysis request triggers the security-analyzer agent.' This helps Claude understand triggering conditions.

faq.question: How do I test if my agent triggers correctly?
faq.answer: Create test scenarios using similar phrasing to your examples. Use the agent in real situations and verify it triggers when expected. Check that the agent follows its system prompt process steps and produces the defined output format.
